item.title: Online Sports Betting: History, Evolution and Trends for the Future
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
The world of sports betting underwent a radical transformation over the past few decades, particularly with the rise of online platforms. The history of sports betting dates back to ancient civilizations, but it is only in recent years that the internet changed how bets are placed and how the industry operates. Today, online sports betting is a multi-billion-dollar industry that spans the globe, bringing together technology, regulation and a passion for sports in new and exciting ways. In this article, therefore, inplaySoft will explain the history and evolution of this popular form of entertainment and explore some of the main trends for the future!

History of Sports Betting

The origins of sports betting trace back to the ancient Greeks and Romans, who placed wagers on athletic competitions and chariot races. Ancient Greeks famously used the Olympic Games to gamble, and the practice of betting on sporting events was well-documented in Roman society as well. These early forms of betting involved personal stakes and informal wagers among individuals.

In the modern era, sports betting began to formalize with the rise of horse racing in the 19th century. The United Kingdom introduced the first legal betting systems with the establishment of racetracks and regulated betting shops. By the 20th century, the expansion of sports like football (soccer), baseball and basketball allowed for the proliferation of betting markets, which were regulated and controlled by various government entities across different countries.

The United States also has a long tradition of sports betting, particularly on horse racing. However, until the 1990s, betting on most sports outside of horse racing was either illegal or heavily restricted. The major turning point for sports betting in the U.S. came with the passage of the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (PASPA) in 1992, which effectively banned sports betting outside of Nevada.

Online Sports Betting

The birth of online sports betting occurred in the mid-to-late 1990s, when the internet began to gain popularity. In 1996, the first online sportsbook was launched, offering bettors the opportunity to place wagers on various sports from the comfort of their own homes. This innovation changed the game, as it eliminated the need for bettors to physically visit a sportsbook or casino. Instead, bettors could access online platforms through their computers, which quickly proved to be a major convenience.

By the late 1990s and early 2000s, the online sports betting market exploded, driven by increasing internet access, technological advancements and the global rise of the internet as a platform for commerce. Betting websites began to dominate the scene, offering bettors a wide range of sports to wager on, from traditional events like football and basketball to more niche options like darts, snooker, and eSports.

Regulation and Legislation

As the online sports betting industry grew, so did the need for regulation. Governments across the world began to recognize the economic benefits of legalizing and regulating online sports betting, especially in terms of tax revenue. However, the regulatory landscape is complex and varies by country.

In the United States, the fight over sports betting reached a boiling point when PASPA was overturned by the Supreme Court in May 2018. This landmark decision allowed individual states to legalize and regulate sports betting within their borders. The decision opened the door for an explosion of legal sports betting across the country. States like New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Colorado were quick to embrace the opportunity, and as of 2025, over 30 states legalized some form of sports betting, generating billions of dollars in revenue.

Meanwhile, in the United Kingdom, the government regulates online sports betting since the Gambling Act of 2005, which provided a clear framework for online operators. The UK’s model served as a template for many other countries that seek to regulate online gambling. The European Union also enacted laws to harmonize online gambling regulations, allowing for cross-border betting between member states.

Evolution of Online Sports Betting

Online sports betting evolved significantly since its inception. A few key developments that shaped the industry in recent years are:

  • Mobile Betting: one of the most significant evolutions in online sports betting was the rise of mobile betting apps. As smartphones became more ubiquitous, online sportsbooks developed mobile-friendly platforms, which allowed users to place bets on-the-go. This development made sports betting more convenient and contributed to a rise in mobile-first bettors.
  • Live Betting and In-Play Markets: another major shift in online sports betting was the introduction of live betting, also known as in-play betting. This allows bettors to place wagers during an ongoing game, with odds constantly updated in real-time. In-play betting became incredibly popular, as it provides a more dynamic and interactive betting experience. Bettors, for instance, can wager on various events during a football match, such as the next team to score or the outcome of a particular possession.
  • Betting Exchanges: unlike traditional sportsbooks that set odds and accept bets, betting exchanges allow bettors to act as both the bookmaker and the bettor. These exchanges create a marketplace where users can bet against each other, with the platform acting as an intermediary to facilitate the bets. Betting exchanges became increasingly popular for their transparency and better odds, as bettors are able to set their own terms.
  • Cash-Out Features: many sportsbooks offer "cash-out" features, which allow bettors to settle a bet before the event is over. This feature allows users to lock in profits or minimize losses based on the state of the event. If a bettor places a wager on a team to win a game and the team is performing better than expected, for example, they can cash out early for a guaranteed profit, even before the game ends.
  • Data and Analytics: sports betting always relied on statistical analysis, but the advent of big data and artificial intelligence revolutionized how bettors analyze trends, player performance and match outcomes. Today, sophisticated algorithms and machine learning models can predict the likelihood of certain outcomes with incredible accuracy, giving bettors an edge in their wagers.

Trends for the Future of Online Sports Betting

Some of the key trends that are likely to shape the trajectory of online sports betting are:

  • Integration of Virtual and Augmented Reality: virtual and augmented reality technologies hold the potential to take online sports betting to the next level. Imagine watching a live sports event in a fully immersive 3D environment while placing bets on various aspects of the game. This could change the way users experience sports and gambling, making the entire process more interactive and engaging.
  • eSports Betting: the rise of competitive video gaming, or eSports, created a new frontier for online sports betting. With tournaments drawing millions of viewers and players, eSports betting is growing rapidly. This market will likely continue to expand, with major bookmakers offering odds on various games and tournaments.
  • Crypto and Blockchain Technology: cryptocurrencies already begun to make inroads into online betting platforms. Blockchain technology offers benefits like transparency, security and faster transactions, making it a natural fit for the world of online sports betting. As digital currencies become more mainstream, we can expect more betting sites to adopt these payment methods.
  • Global Expansion and Regulation: as more countries legalize and regulate online sports betting, the market will continue to expand globally. While regulation will help curb illegal betting, it will also require operators to adapt to local laws and consumer preferences. The challenge for sportsbooks will be balancing innovation with compliance, ensuring that bettors are protected and that the industry remains sustainable.

Final thoughts

The evolution of online sports betting has been nothing short of transformative, moving from humble beginnings to a thriving global industry. With advancements in mobile technology, live betting, data analytics and emerging trends, like eSports and blockchain, the future of online sports betting looks exciting. However, as the industry continues to grow, regulation and consumer protection will remain paramount. The future will undoubtedly bring new opportunities and challenges, but one thing is clear: the world of online sports betting is here to stay, and it will continue to evolve in innovative and unexpected ways.

Online sports betting became a multibillion-dollar industry in the last few years and should continue to evolve with technological advancements.

item.title: American vs. European Roulette: Differences, Similarities and Tips for Players
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
Roulette is one of the most iconic casino games. Its allure stems from its simple rules, elegant wheel and the potential for big payouts. However, not all roulette wheels are the same. Players can encounter two distinct types of roulette in casinos worldwide: American and European. Both share the same basic concept, but there are key differences in their design and gameplay that can influence odds and strategies. In this article, inplaySoft will explore the differences and similarities between American and European roulette, as well as offer some useful tips to maximize the chances of winning.

Similarities Between American and European Roulette

At the heart of both American and European roulette lies the same basic concept: a wheel with numbered pockets, a ball that is spun around the wheel and players who place bets on where they think the ball will land. The rules and the overall gameplay experience are nearly identical, with the primary goal being to predict the correct number or category of numbers that the ball will land on. The core similarities are:

  • Basic Layout: both versions feature a roulette wheel divided into numbered pockets. In European roulette, there are 37 pockets (1-36 plus a single zero), while in American roulette, there are 38 pockets (1-36, a single zero, and a double zero). Despite this difference, the basic layout of the betting table is nearly identical in both versions.
  • Betting Options: both versions offer a variety of betting options. Players can place inside bets (on individual numbers or small groups of numbers) or outside bets (on large categories such as red or black, odd or even, or high or low). The types of bets available are the same in both American and European roulette, offering players flexibility and strategy options.
  • Wheel Rotation: the roulette wheel operates in the same manner in both versions. The dealer spins the wheel in one direction while dropping the ball in the opposite direction. Players place their bets and the ball eventually lands in one of the pockets. If the ball lands in a pocket that corresponds to a player's bet, they win according to the payout odds.
  • Payouts: the payout structure in both versions of roulette is the same for all types of bets. A straight-up bet on a single number, for instance, pays 35 to 1 in both versions, while a bet on red or black pays 1 to 1. The differences in the odds between American and European roulette are a result of the added pocket in the American version.

Differences Between American and European Roulette

The most noticeable difference between American and European roulette lies in the design of the roulette wheel, which affects the odds of winning and the house edge.

  1. Number of Pockets
    • European Roulette: the European roulette wheel features 37 pockets, numbered from 0 to 36. The presence of a single zero means that there is a lower house edge for players.
    • American Roulette: the American roulette wheel, on the other hand, contains 38 pockets. In addition to the numbers 1 to 36 and a single zero, it includes a second green pocket, labeled "00" (double zero). This extra pocket increases the house edge and decreases the player's chances of winning.
  2. House Edge

The house edge refers to the advantage the casino has over the player in any given game. The difference in the number of pockets has a significant impact on the house edge.

  • European Roulette: with only a single zero pocket, the house edge is 2.7%. This means that for every $100 wagered, the casino expects to keep $2.70 on average over the long term.
  • American Roulette: the additional double zero pocket increases the house edge to 5.26%. This means that for every $100 wagered, the casino keeps $5.26 on average over time. The increased house edge in American roulette means that players have a lower probability of winning in this version of the game compared to European roulette.
  1. The En Prison and La Partage Rules

In many European roulette games, players benefit from special rules that further reduce the house edge on even-money bets:

  • La Partage: this rule allows players to recover half of their bet if the ball lands on zero when they’ve made an even-money bet (such as red or black, odd or even). This rule effectively halves the house edge on those bets, reducing it to 1.35%.
  • En Prison: similar to La Partage, the En Prison rule allows players to keep their bet “in prison” for the next spin if the ball lands on zero. If the next spin is successful, the bet is returned to the player, but if not, the casino takes the bet. This rule also reduces the house edge for even-money bets. These rules are typically not present in American roulette, further tilting the odds in favor of the casino.

Tips for Players

Understanding the differences between American and European roulette can help players make better decisions. Here are a few tips to keep in mind when playing roulette:

  • Prefer European Roulette: if you have the choice, always opt for European roulette. With a single zero and a lower house edge, it offers better odds than American roulette, making it a smarter choice for players who want to maximize their chances of winning.
  • Understand the House Edge: be aware of how the house edge works in both versions of roulette. In American roulette, the added double zero increases the house edge, meaning your money will likely be at risk more quickly. This makes betting strategies like the Martingale (doubling bets after a loss) more volatile and less effective in American roulette.
  • Take Advantage of Special Rules: if you’re playing European roulette, look for games that offer the La Partage or En Prison rules. These rules reduce the house edge on even-money bets and give players a better chance to win.
  • Manage Your Bankroll: always set a budget before sitting down at the table. Roulette can be an exciting game, but it can also deplete your funds quickly if you're not careful. Stick to your bankroll and don’t chase losses.
  • Know Your Bets: while inside bets on individual numbers have higher payouts, they also carry higher risk. Outside bets, such as red or black, odd or even, and high or low, offer lower payouts but are more likely to win. If you're aiming for more consistent wins, outside bets may be the way to go.

Final thoughts

While American and European roulette share many similarities, the differences between them, particularly the number of pockets and the house edge, have a significant impact on gameplay. European roulette offers better odds due to its single zero, and players can benefit from rules like La Partage and En Prison. On the other hand, American roulette has a higher house edge due to the additional double zero pocket, making it a less favorable option for most players.

By understanding the differences between these two versions and using smart strategies, players can enhance their enjoyment of roulette and improve their chances of winning. Whether playing for fun or aiming for serious payouts, knowledge of the game’s mechanics is key to making good decisions and managing bets effectively.

item.title: Online Poker: History, Evolution and Main Types
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
Online poker is one of the most popular forms of entertainment and gambling in the world. Its roots trace back to the early days of the internet and its evolution shaped the way people experience the game today. From its humble beginnings in the mid-1990s to its current status as a multibillion-dollar industry, online poker experienced a rapid and dynamic transformation. In this article, inplaySoft will explore the history, evolution and the main types of online poker.

History of Online Poker

The history of online poker is intertwined with the development of the internet and its impact on various industries. Poker, a game with origins dating back hundreds of years, was traditionally played in brick-and-mortar casinos or among friends in private settings. However, as the internet began to grow in popularity during the 1990s, the opportunity to play poker online became a reality.

The Early Days of online poker: 1990s

The first significant step towards online poker was the creation of online casinos. In 1994, Antigua and Barbuda passed the Free Trade & Processing Act, which allowed for online gambling. This opened the door for companies to operate online casinos and poker rooms, although they were still limited in terms of technology and user reach.

The first online poker game was launched in 1998 by a company called "Planet Poker." This platform allowed players to connect through the internet and play against each other in real time. The software was rudimentary and the graphics were basic, but it was a groundbreaking development at the time. It didn't take long for other companies to see the potential of the online poker market and, in 1999, another online poker site, Paradise Poker, began operations and attracted more attention from poker enthusiasts.

The introduction of online poker also coincided with the rise of internet gambling, which quickly became a global phenomenon. As more players started to discover the joys of poker on the internet, the game began to take on new forms, allowing players to access poker rooms from the comfort of their own homes.

The Online Poker Boom: Early 2000s

Online poker experienced significant growth in the early 2000s, particularly with the emergence of "real money" poker sites. One of the most influential events in the history of online poker was the creation of PokerStars in 2001. PokerStars, which started as a small poker room, eventually became the largest online poker site in the world. Its success was largely driven by the development of user-friendly interfaces, fast transactions and a broad range of games for players of all levels.

In 2003, online poker took on a new level of visibility when Chris Moneymaker, an amateur player, won the World Series of Poker (WSOP) Main Event after qualifying through an online satellite tournament. His victory, often referred to as the "Moneymaker Effect," sparked a surge in interest in online poker, leading to a massive increase in the number of players and poker sites.

The popularity of online poker exploded in the mid-2000s, with sites such as Full Tilt Poker, PartyPoker, and PokerStars dominating the market. The game reached a global audience, with millions of players competing against each other. Major televised poker events, such as the WSOP, became prime-time television programming, drawing even more attention to the game.

The UIGEA and Its Impact: 2006-2010

Despite its meteoric rise, online poker faced significant challenges, particularly in the United States. In 2006, the passage of the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act (UIGEA) made it illegal for banks to process payments related to online gambling, including online poker. This law created a wave of uncertainty and forced several major poker sites to cease operations in the U.S.

However, online poker continued to thrive in other parts of the world. PokerStars, Full Tilt Poker, and other sites moved to jurisdictions where online poker was regulated and legal. The UIGEA didn’t stop the growth of online poker globally, but it did lead to a shift in the way poker rooms operated.

Legalization and Regulation: 2010-Present

In recent years, the legal landscape for online poker changed dramatically in certain regions. Starting in 2011, states like Nevada, Delaware and New Jersey in the U.S. began to legalize online poker, offering regulated platforms where players could compete for real money. This shift towards legalization also led to the development of shared liquidity agreements, where players from different states could play against one another in online poker tournaments and cash games.

Globally, online poker continued to expand, with many countries taking steps to regulate and tax the industry. The growth of mobile technology also played a significant role in the accessibility of online poker, allowing players to engage in games on their smartphones and tablets.

Evolution of Online Poker

The evolution of online poker was shaped by a variety of factors, including advances in technology, the demand for innovation and the needs of players. The game evolved from a simple, text-based interface to a fully immersive experience with high-definition graphics, live dealer options and various game formats.

Technological Advancements

Online poker benefited from rapid advancements in technology. In the early days, the game's interface was rudimentary, with little to no visual elements. As internet speeds improved and graphic design became more sophisticated, poker platforms were able to offer more engaging and visually appealing experiences. Today, online poker rooms offer sleek, polished interfaces with 3D avatars, customizable tables and real-time chat features that enhance the social aspect of the game.

The rise of mobile devices was also a game-changer. Online poker sites now offer mobile applications, allowing players to play poker anytime, anywhere. This accessibility contributed to the game's growth and popularity.

Game Formats and Innovations

Another key evolution in online poker was the introduction of new game formats and innovations. Online poker sites, for instance, offer a variety of poker types, including Texas Hold’em, Omaha, Seven-Card Stud and more niche variations. Tournaments, including sit-and-go events and multi-table tournaments (MTTs), provide players with different ways to compete for prizes.

One of the most notable innovations was the introduction of "fast-fold" poker, which allows players to quickly fold hands and move to a new table, offering a faster-paced, more action-packed experience.

Main Types of Online Poker

Online poker offers a variety of game types to suit different player preferences. Some of the most popular types are:

Texas Hold'em

Texas Hold’em is by far the most popular form of poker played online. It is the primary game in most online poker rooms and major live tournaments, like the World Series of Poker. The game involves two hole cards dealt to each player and five community cards that are shared by all players. The goal is to make the best five-card hand using a combination of hole cards and community cards.

Omaha

Omaha is similar to Texas Hold'em, but differs in that each player is dealt four hole cards instead of two. The objective is to create the best possible hand using exactly two of the hole cards and three of the community cards. Omaha is often considered a more complex variant and attracts skilled players.

Seven-Card Stud

Seven-Card Stud was one of the most popular poker variants before Texas Hold’em took over. In Seven-Card Stud, there are no community cards. Each player is dealt seven cards, three of which are face-down and four face-up. The goal is to make the best five-card hand possible from the seven cards dealt.

Razz

Razz is a form of Seven-Card Stud where the goal is to make the lowest possible hand. Straights and flushes don’t count against you, making it a unique and intriguing variant for experienced players.

Pineapple and Crazy Pineapple

Pineapple and Crazy Pineapple are variants of Texas Hold'em where players are dealt three hole cards. Crazy Pineapple requires players to discard a card after the flop, adding an extra layer of strategy.

Final thoughts

Online poker underwent significant evolution since its inception, with advancements in technology, game formats and player preferences driving its growth. From its humble beginnings in the 1990s to the global phenomenon it is today, online poker captured the imaginations of millions. With numerous variations and innovations, online poker continues to evolve and offer players endless hours of entertainment and competition. As the industry adapts to legal and technological changes, the future of online poker looks bright.

item.title: Bets on betting platforms could reach R$ 30 billion per month in Brazil by 2025
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
According to the Banco Central (Central Bank) of Brazil, bets on betting platforms could reach up to R$ 30 billion per month in the country by 2025. This data was presented last week in the Brazilian Senate by Gabriel Galípolo, president of the Banco Central, during a session of the “CPI das Bets”, a parliamentary inquiry commission that aims to clarify the impact of digital betting on the financial health of Brazilians.

On the same day, Rogério Lucca, executive secretary of the Central Bank, said that currently between R$ 20 billion and R$ 30 billion are already being wagered monthly in betting platforms in Brazil. 

The Central Bank presented the data of a study in 2024 that estimated Brazilians spent R$ 20 billion per month, but at the time the research was done the betting platforms were still not regulated in the country. With new regulations in place, it will be possible to assess this number more accurately in future studies. 

“Now with more concrete data, we confirm the figure of R$ 20 billion, and more recently, it may reach R$ 30 billion per month. So far this year, from January to March, the amount we’ve been tracking is around R$ 20 billion to R$ 30 billion per month”, said Rogério Lucca.

The good news for the bettors is that, as Lucca emphasized, a significant portion of that amount, estimated at over 90%, is returned to them as payouts for their wagers.

Bettors have higher credit risk

A study by Banco Central also showed that individuals who engage in online betting have significantly higher credit risk than those who don't, said Gabriel Galípolo. "Banks consider this type of behavior when analyzing and classifying someone as a higher-risk individual. Ultimately, it leads to higher costs for them," he said.

Galípolo cited a study indicating that a significant number of bettors viewed betting as an investment alternative. As a result, Banco Central has been promoting financial education initiatives for the population.

Central Bank of Brazil and regulation of betting platforms

BC is not responsible for penalizing financial institutions involved in illegal betting

During the CPI session, senators questioned Banco Central’s role in supervising and penalizing financial institutions involved in illegal betting operations. As Galípolo pointed out, the institution does not have the power to regulate betting platforms. “Banco Central does not have the legal authority to regulate or impose sanctions on fixed-odds betting transactions carried out by unauthorized legal entities,” Galípolo stated.

The authority to sanction these institutions lies with the Secretariat of Prizes and Betting under the Ministry of Finance. “A financial institution, although authorized by us, can be sanctioned in various ways, by the IRS, fire department, etc. Who sanctions depends on the activity that’s triggering the sanction, and in the case of betting, that’s not us”, said Galípolo.

Changes in Brazil's regulation

In December 2023, Brazil approved Law 14.790/23. Among the main changes imposed by it, private companies will now be able to operate sports betting both online and in physical establishments.

See, below, how this Law will affect sports betting in the country:

  • Private companies will be able to operate both online and in physical establishments: until December 2023, sports betting in Brazil was only allowed in lottery shops and was controlled by the federal government. As of January of this year, however, any private company will be able to operate sports betting, whether digitally or in a physical space.
  • The minimum age for placing sports bets has increased from 18 to 21 years old.
  • Advertisements or any type of publicity targeted at minors have been prohibited.
  • Betters must have their identity verified and validated;
  • Bookmakers must implement policies to prevent money laundering schemes and promote responsible gambling.

How will sports betting regulation work in Brazil?

It is important to note that, in 2023, Provisional Measure (MP) No. 1.182/2023 was also approved, amending Law 13.756/18. Among other changes, this law allows for more control of the sports betting sector. For example:

  • Monitoring: betting houses will have to purchase a license to operate in Brazil. The tendency is for a new department to be created in the Ministry of Finance to accredit companies, after a process of document analysis. If approved, the government will monitor the volume of bets and the institutions' revenue, which will ensure more control over this market.
  • Legality: companies approved in the process mentioned above and with valid licenses will be able to receive bets related to sporting events. These events, however, must be official and organized by federations, leagues or confederations. Betting houses that commit infractions may be fined between 0.1% and 20% of the proceeds of the revenue, depending on the severity of the violation.
  • Taxes: players with winnings exceeding R$2,112 will have to pay 30% of the value of their total winnings in taxes, which is the same rate applied to lottery prizes. Betting houses, in turn, must be required to pay an 18% tax on Gross Gaming Revenue (GGR), which is the revenue obtained from all games played, minus prizes paid to players and taxes levied on legal entities. Companies in the sector, like any other, will also need to pay PIS, Cofins, Income Tax, CSLL and ISS.
  • Money laundering: betting houses must implement strict control and effective monitoring systems to prevent money laundering. They must submit information about bettors to the Financial Activities Control Council (Coaf).

Bookmakers also need to promote awareness-raising actions regarding pathological gambling disorder, to prevent addiction and ensure the mental health of bettors.

item.title: Brazilian Senator says that bill to legalize games and casinos is ready for voting
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
The decision to put the bill to legalize casinos, bingo halls and Jogo do Bicho in Brazil is now in the hands of Davi Alcolumbre, President of the House. The statement was made by Senator Irajá, the bill’s rapporteur, who also said that it has a mature text and already has the necessary votes for approval.

“It is ready to be discussed and voted on in the plenary, as soon as our president Davi understands that the environment is suitable for voting,” he said in an interview to Poder360. “I am open to dialogue, including with the evangelical bench, which has taken a very firm position against the approval of this matter. I believe in common sense,” he added.

According to Senator Irajá, the legalization of these gambling activities will bring R$ 22 billion in taxes to Brazil’s government and might double the number of tourists in the country, from 6 million to 12 million per year.

Responsible gambling

When asked about issues related to gambling addiction and sports betting addiction, Senator Irajá said that “of the 38 OECD (Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development) countries, only Iceland has not yet approved responsible gambling. If you take into account the G20, which are the 20 largest economies in the world, only Brazil and Indonesia have not legalized it”.

“If you look at South America, out of 13 countries, only Brazil and Bolivia did not have the courage to confront this issue yet. I am particularly convinced that we have enough votes to approve this matter. Brazil, which ranks 50th in international tourism, cannot sit back and allow itself the luxury of not taking advantage of this great opportunity to generate jobs, income and taxes,” he concluded.

Bets could reach R$ 30 billion per month

Earlier this month, Gabriel Galípolo, president of the Banco Central of Brazil, said that bets on betting platforms could reach up to R$ 30 billion per month in the country by 2025.

Banco Central presented the data of a study in 2024 that estimated Brazilians spent R$ 20 billion per month, but at the time the research was done the betting platforms were still not regulated in the country. With new regulations in place, it will be possible to assess this number more accurately in future studies. 

“Now with more concrete data, we confirm the figure of R$ 20 billion, and more recently, it may reach R$ 30 billion per month. So far this year, from January to March, the amount we’ve been tracking is around R$ 20 billion to R$ 30 billion per month”, said Rogério Lucca,  executive secretary of Banco Central.

The good news for the bettors is that, as Lucca emphasized, a significant portion of that amount, estimated at over 90%, is returned to them as payouts for their wagers.

Changes in Brazilian regulation

In December 2023, Brazil approved Law 14.790/23. Among the main changes imposed by it, private companies will now be able to operate sports betting both online and in physical establishments.

See, below, how this Law will affect sports betting in the country:

  • Private companies will be able to operate both online and in physical establishments: until December 2023, sports betting in Brazil was only allowed in lottery shops and was controlled by the federal government. As of January of this year, however, any private company will be able to operate sports betting, whether digitally or in a physical space.
  • The minimum age for placing sports bets has increased from 18 to 21 years old.
  • Advertisements or any type of publicity targeted at minors have been prohibited.
  • Betters must have their identity verified and validated;
  • Bookmakers must implement policies to prevent money laundering schemes and promote responsible gambling.

How will sports betting regulation work in Brazil?

It is important to note that, in 2023, Provisional Measure (MP) No. 1.182/2023 was also approved, amending Law 13.756/18. Among other changes, this law allows for more control of the sports betting sector. For example:

  • Monitoring: betting houses will have to purchase a license to operate in Brazil. The tendency is for a new department to be created in the Ministry of Finance to accredit companies, after a process of document analysis. If approved, the government will monitor the volume of bets and the institutions' revenue, which will ensure more control over this market.
  • Legality: companies approved in the process mentioned above and with valid licenses will be able to receive bets related to sporting events. These events, however, must be official and organized by federations, leagues or confederations. Betting houses that commit infractions may be fined between 0.1% and 20% of the proceeds of the revenue, depending on the severity of the violation.
  • Taxes: players with winnings exceeding R$2,112 will have to pay 30% of the value of their total winnings in taxes, which is the same rate applied to lottery prizes. Betting houses, in turn, must be required to pay an 18% tax on Gross Gaming Revenue (GGR), which is the revenue obtained from all games played, minus prizes paid to players and taxes levied on legal entities. Companies in the sector, like any other, will also need to pay PIS, Cofins, Income Tax, CSLL and ISS.
  • Money laundering: betting houses must implement strict control and effective monitoring systems to prevent money laundering. They must submit information about bettors to the Financial Activities Control Council (Coaf).

Bookmakers also need to promote awareness-raising actions regarding pathological gambling disorder, to prevent addiction and ensure the mental health of bettors.

item.title: Brazil’s government publishes schedule for regulating Bets in the country
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
Brazil’s government published last week a schedule aimed at regulating sports betting websites for 2025 and 2026. According to the ordinance, made by the Secretariat of Prizes and Betting of the Ministry of Finance, the regulation focuses on three main pillars: promoting responsible gambling, aimed at bettors struggling with addiction; creating a balanced regulatory environment, with good compliance practices; and strengthening oversight by the Ministry of Finance.

First initiatives

The first initiatives, which the government expects to complete by June, include the development and implementation of a platform - with rules for data consultation and sharing - for self-excluded bettors or those prohibited from gambling. In addition, the Ministry plans to define the parameters for creating a distinctive seal that informs the bettor whether the environment they are in is operated by a safe agent approved by the federal government.

In July, measures such as the modernization of procedures related to the commercial promotion of games and the regulation of the entire economic chain associated with betting operators, such as online game providers, aggregators, and other service providers, are expected to be implemented.

Next steps

By the end of 2025, the government plans to establish a National Betting System, coordinated with states and municipalities, to “promote best practices and minimum national standards for responsible gambling, technical requirements for systems and games, and efforts to combat money laundering.” 

The timeline also includes the development of an initiative aimed at customer service channels to “help preserve the mental health” of bettors and to mitigate “harm associated with the activity”, such as addiction and bankruptcy.

Regulation in Brazil

The regulation of the sports betting market in Brazil came into effect on January 1st of 2025. According to the ANJL (National Association of Games and Lotteries), the regulated online betting market in Brazil is expected to have an economic impact this year, generating approximately R$ 20 billion in taxes and fees. This estimated amount includes federal grants and a 12% fee on GGR (Gross Gaming Revenue), a metric that calculates gross revenue from different betting models, as well as the regular taxes applied to the services sector.

The total tax burden will be 36%, which establishes Brazil as one of the largest betting markets in Latin America, with the potential to rank among the four largest in the world. The ANJL also forecasts the creation of 60 thousand direct and indirect jobs with the regulation of the betting sector, which will boost areas such as information technology, advertising, media, law, and compliance.

Law No. 14,790 of 2023, which regulates the sector, stipulates that part of the revenue will be allocated to the Ministry of Health for initiatives aimed at the prevention and treatment of gambling addiction.

Click here to see the official schedule.

item.title: Traffic to Betting Platforms Grows 90% in Brazil After Regulation
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
After Brazil changed its legislation and regulations in the last year, the traffic in betting platforms increased 90%. According to a survey conducted by the website Aposta Legal, iGaming sites received more than 5 billion visits in the first quarter of 2025. This volume of visits is equivalent to over 650 pages accessed per second.

The regulated betting period began in the country in January 2025. In that month, there were 1.7 billion visits to betting platforms, followed by 1.4 billion visits in February, and 1.8 billion in March. Compared to the previous quarter, the average number of visits to iGaming sites increased by 90%. 

Sigap Receives Over 500 Million Daily Records Related to Online Gaming

After the regulation of betting in Brazil, the Betting Management System (Sigap) began overseeing the activities of this industry in the country. In just over three months, the system monitored millions of data points from legalized gambling companies.

Sigap was developed by the Federal Data Processing Service (Serpro) for the SPA, part of the Ministry of Finance. “With just three months since operators started sending data, the system has already received approximately 500,000 sports betting files, 330,000 online gaming files, 600,000 wallet files, and 260,000 bettor records, totaling 1.69 million files in the database. This represents an average of 500 million daily records (each file can contain up to 7,000 records), with 77 authorized operators and 174 brands operating in this sector,” explained Kamila Duarte, manager at Serpro.

Bets on betting platforms could reach R$ 30 billion per month in Brazil

According to the Banco Central (Central Bank) of Brazil, bets on betting platforms could reach up to R$ 30 billion per month in the country by 2025. This data was presented last week in the Brazilian Senate by Gabriel Galípolo, president of the Banco Central, during a session of the “CPI das Bets”, a parliamentary inquiry commission that aims to clarify the impact of digital betting on the financial health of Brazilians.

On the same day, Rogério Lucca, executive secretary of the Central Bank, said that currently between R$ 20 billion and R$ 30 billion are already being wagered monthly in betting platforms in Brazil. 

The Central Bank presented the data of a study in 2024 that estimated Brazilians spent R$ 20 billion per month, but at the time the research was done the betting platforms were still not regulated in the country. With new regulations in place, it will be possible to assess this number more accurately in future studies. 

“Now with more concrete data, we confirm the figure of R$ 20 billion, and more recently, it may reach R$ 30 billion per month. So far this year, from January to March, the amount we’ve been tracking is around R$ 20 billion to R$ 30 billion per month”, said Rogério Lucca.

The good news for the bettors is that, as Lucca emphasized, a significant portion of that amount, estimated at over 90%, is returned to them as payouts for their wagers.

In December 2023, Brazil approved Law 14.790/23. Among the main changes imposed by it, private companies will now be able to operate sports betting both online and in physical establishments.

See, below, how this Law will affect sports betting in the country:

  • Private companies will be able to operate both online and in physical establishments: until December 2023, sports betting in Brazil was only allowed in lottery shops and was controlled by the federal government. As of January of this year, however, any private company will be able to operate sports betting, whether digitally or in a physical space.
  • The minimum age for placing sports bets has increased from 18 to 21 years old.
  • Advertisements or any type of publicity targeted at minors have been prohibited.
  • Betters must have their identity verified and validated;
  • Bookmakers must implement policies to prevent money laundering schemes and promote responsible gambling.

How will sports betting regulation work in Brazil?

It is important to note that, in 2023, Provisional Measure (MP) No. 1.182/2023 was also approved, amending Law 13.756/18. Among other changes, this law allows for more control of the sports betting sector. For example:

  • Monitoring: betting houses will have to purchase a license to operate in Brazil. The tendency is for a new department to be created in the Ministry of Finance to accredit companies, after a process of document analysis. If approved, the government will monitor the volume of bets and the institutions' revenue, which will ensure more control over this market.
  • Legality: companies approved in the process mentioned above and with valid licenses will be able to receive bets related to sporting events. These events, however, must be official and organized by federations, leagues or confederations. Betting houses that commit infractions may be fined between 0.1% and 20% of the proceeds of the revenue, depending on the severity of the violation.
  • Taxes: players with winnings exceeding R$2,112 will have to pay 30% of the value of their total winnings in taxes, which is the same rate applied to lottery prizes. Betting houses, in turn, must be required to pay an 18% tax on Gross Gaming Revenue (GGR), which is the revenue obtained from all games played, minus prizes paid to players and taxes levied on legal entities. Companies in the sector, like any other, will also need to pay PIS, Cofins, Income Tax, CSLL and ISS.
  • Money laundering: betting houses must implement strict control and effective monitoring systems to prevent money laundering. They must submit information about bettors to the Financial Activities Control Council (Coaf).

Bookmakers also need to promote awareness-raising actions regarding pathological gambling disorder, to prevent addiction and ensure the mental health of bettors.

item.title: Brazil expands list of esports and games allowed for online betting
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
Brazil expanded last week the list of esports and online games that are allowed in online betting. The change was made official on Wednesday, April 23, and confirmed by the Minister of Sports, André Fufuca.

In an ordinance, the Ministry of Sports changed the law Nº 14.790/2023, that determines which types of online games are eligible for fixed-odds bets. The federal government now authorizes online betting for esports tournaments that have a "license or authorization from the developers" or owners of the "intellectual property of the games."

Previously, the government considered only esports recognized by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to be eligible, which excluded shooting games such as Counter Strike, Valorant and Fortnite. Some of the games considered esports by the IOC are baseball, chess, cycling, Just Dance, motorsport, target shooting, tennis, among others.

The IOC had already excluded shooting games from the categories included in the esports Olympic Games. The Committee's director of virtual sports and games, Vincent Pereira, stated, when referring to these games, that "we cannot have these games promoting Olympic values."

Fortnite, a survival shooter game, was included in the 2023 Olympic esports Week, but it was played in a shooting sports format rather than in its traditional format.

Online Betting

In December 2018, Brazil approved Law 13,756 and established the fixed-odds betting modality in the country, determining that these are "bets related to real or virtual events in which it is defined, at the time of placing the bet, how much the bettor can win if the prediction is correct".

Then, on December 31, 2023, the government sanctioned the law that regulates the online sports betting market in Brazil. According to the Law, only companies with headquarters and administration in Brazil may operate sports betting. Minors under the age of 18 may not place bets, as well as: 

  • Owners and people who work at betting companies;
  • Public agents involved in the regulation and supervision of the betting market;
  • People who have access to the computerized betting system;
  • People who have or may have influence over the outcome of games, such as sports directors, referees and athletes;
  • People diagnosed with gambling addiction, which is a compulsive gambling disorder.

Traffic to Betting Platforms Grows 90% in Brazil After Regulation

After Brazil changed its legislation and regulations in the last year, the traffic in betting platforms increased 90%. According to a survey conducted by the website Aposta Legal, iGaming sites received more than 5 billion visits in the first quarter of 2025. This volume of visits is equivalent to over 650 pages accessed per second.

The regulated betting period began in the country in January 2025. In that month, there were 1.7 billion visits to betting platforms, followed by 1.4 billion visits in February, and 1.8 billion in March. Compared to the previous quarter, the average number of visits to iGaming sites increased by 90%. 

Bets on betting platforms could reach R$ 30 billion per month in Brazil

According to the Banco Central (Central Bank) of Brazil, bets on betting platforms could reach up to R$ 30 billion per month in the country by 2025. This data was presented in the Brazilian Senate by Gabriel Galípolo, president of the Banco Central, during a session of the “CPI das Bets”, a parliamentary inquiry commission that aims to clarify the impact of digital betting on the financial health of Brazilians.

The Central Bank presented the data of a study in 2024 that estimated Brazilians spent R$ 20 billion per month, but at the time the research was done the betting platforms were still not regulated in the country. With new regulations in place, it will be possible to assess this number more accurately in future studies. 

“Now with more concrete data, we confirm the figure of R$ 20 billion, and more recently, it may reach R$ 30 billion per month. So far this year, from January to March, the amount we’ve been tracking is around R$ 20 billion to R$ 30 billion per month”, said Rogério Lucca, executive secretary of the Central Bank.

The good news for the bettors is that, as Lucca emphasized, a significant portion of that amount, estimated at over 90%, is returned to them as payouts for their wagers.

item.title: Bets are Related to the Lower Classes, Right? Wrong
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
More than 15% of Brazilians, or over 23 million people, made at least one sporting bet in 2024. The number was released in the eighth edition of the study Raio X do Investidor Brasileiro, conducted by the Brazilian Association of Financial and Capital Market Entities (Anbima) and Datafolha.

The research also showed that more Brazilians made bets than invested in most financial products, such as Bank Deposit Certificates (CDBs, purchased by 10 million people) and investment funds (purchased by 9 million people). Furthermore, bettors are a larger group than investors in cryptocurrencies (purchased by 6 million people) and stocks (purchased by 5 million people). 

Profile of the Brazilian Bettor

The study also investigated the profile of the Brazilian bettor. Regarding sex and age, the majority identified as men from generation Z (16 to 28 years old). As to social class, 16% of bettor are from classes A and B, while 17% are from class C and 10% from classes D and E.

 "The assessment that bets are related to the lower classes is not true", said Marcelo Billi, superintendent of sustainability, innovation and education at Anbima.

Importance of responsible gambling

Still according to the research, bettors spend, on average, R$ 216 per month on bets. About 47% of them, unfortunately, have debts, and approximately 10%, or 3 million people, have a high tendency to become addicted to bets. "Bets are not a problem in the investment world, but they are a public health problem", added Billi.

The survey also pointed out that about 35% of people with a tendency to gambling addiction invest in financial products. Furthermore, 82% plan to make some investment in 2025. However, 63% are behind on their debts and 71% have a high level of financial stress. 

Among gamblers, 52% tried to recoup their losses by gambling again in 2024. Also, four in ten gamblers mentioned feeling guilty about gambling, and 30% admitted to having bet more money than they could afford to lose. In addition, 10% have had to resort to selling assets or taking out loans to continue gambling. “Gambling disrupts mental and financial health,” said Billi.

However, 59% of gamblers are at the lowest level of addiction, which shows that the practice cannot always be associated with compulsive behavior. Brazilians with a greater tendency to gambling addiction spent an average of R$ 684 per month on bets, about three times more than the average of R$216. Seven out of ten people in this group made at least one bet per week.

Gambling is not an investment

Among bettors, 4 million consider betting to be an investment, which is not true. However, according to the survey, the percentage of the population that believes betting to be an investment fell from 22% in 2023 to 16% in 2024.

Only 43% of bettors also invest in financial products. However, proportionally, there are more bettors among Brazilian investors (17%) than among non-investors (13%). Brazilians who diversify their investments in more than one financial product bet 60% more than the average population. The Brazilians who bet the least are those who invest only in savings.

Betting in Brazil

In December 2018, Brazil approved Law 13,756 and established the fixed-odds betting modality in the country, determining that these are "bets related to real or virtual events in which it is defined, at the time of placing the bet, how much the bettor can win if the prediction is correct".

Then, on December 31, 2023, the government sanctioned the law that regulates the online sports betting market in Brazil. According to the Law, only companies with headquarters and administration in Brazil may operate sports betting. Minors under the age of 18 may not place bets, as well as: 

  • Owners and people who work at betting companies;
  • Public agents involved in the regulation and supervision of the betting market;
  • People who have access to the computerized betting system;
  • People who have or may have influence over the outcome of games, such as sports directors, referees and athletes;
  • People diagnosed with gambling addiction, which is a compulsive gambling disorder.

item.title: Why Responsible Gaming Is Now More Important Than Ever
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
The number of online betting companies in Brazil grew 153% in the country between 2021 and 2024, going from 840 thousand to 2.1 million. The data comes from a research conducted by the datatech company BigDataCorp, which took into account the number of companies licensed to operate with gambling.

The study showed that the Amazonas (3.49%) is the state with the biggest number of betting companies, followed by Ceará (2.66%) and Maranhão (1.29%). Although the North and Northeast regions concentrate almost 20% of betting companies, 64.22% of the money invested in them is in the state of São Paulo. The Federal District, on the other hand, has the highest average per company, with R$ 16.1 million.

Bets in the Brazilian economy

During the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (CPI) on Bets in the Senate, the executive secretary of the Central Bank (BC), Rogério Lucca, stated that between January and March of this year, Brazilians spent up to R$ 30 billion per month on sports betting. Around 93% of this money returns to bettors, according to data from the Secretariat of Prizes and Bets (SPA), an agency of the Ministry of Finance.

In September 2024, the BC published a study on the segment and the profile of bettors. Among other things, it revealed that most of the bets of the 24 million players are made via Pix and the age range of consumers is between 20 and 30 years old, while the average value evolves with age - younger people typically invest R$100 per month, while older people spend more than R$ 3,000 per month.

Responsible gambling

Brazil allows the operation of sports betting companies since 2018. With their growth, the debate about gambling addiction gained ground.

Health experts say that the country is experiencing an epidemic of online gambling addiction. According to a survey of the Brazilian Society of Retail and Consumption (SBVC) and AGP Pesquisas, at least 63% of gamblers compromised their family income, while 19% stopped shopping at the supermarket and 11% stopped buying medicine or spending on healthcare.

The impact on families' income and quality of life is just one of the problems. In addition to money, gambling addiction also affects mental health. In August 2024, the Locomotiva Institute conducted a survey on the epidemic and 60% of respondents stated that gambling affects their emotional state. Among the feelings during the act, 51% said they felt emotional, while 41% said they felt more anxious. Another point that draws attention in the survey is that 30% of respondents stated that online gambling has somehow harmed their personal relationships.

What does the Law say?

To fight addiction, Brazil implemented comprehensive legislation to promote responsible gambling, particularly in the wake of the legalization of online betting. The cornerstone of this regulatory framework is Law No. 14,790/2023, which came into effect on January 1, 2025. This law mandates that betting operators adopt measures to prevent gambling addiction and protect vulnerable individuals.

Key Regulatory Measures

  • Operator Responsibilities: Operators have to implement tools that allow bettors to set daily gambling limits, maximum loss thresholds, pause periods, and self-exclusion options. These measures aim to prevent compulsive gambling behaviors and financial harm.
  • Player Protection: The regulations emphasize the protection of minors and vulnerable populations. Operators must ensure that all bettors are over 18 years of age and implement systems to prevent underage gambling.
  • Advertising Restrictions: Advertising, public relations, and marketing actions for betting operations are regulated to prevent targeting minors and vulnerable individuals. Operators must adhere to specific guidelines to ensure responsible marketing practices.
  • National Self-Exclusion Platform: The Secretariat of Prizes and Bets (SPA) has prioritized the development of a national platform that allows players to self-exclude from gambling activities. This initiative is part of the 2025–2026 regulatory agenda to enhance responsible gambling and prevent addiction.
  • Enhanced Oversight and Penalties: Operators are subject to strict oversight and must comply with regulations to avoid penalties. Non-compliant operators risk suspension or revocation of their licenses.

Contact inplaySoft

At inplaySoft, we view responsible gambling as a cornerstone of ethical iGaming. We believe that the sustainability of the gaming industry is rooted in player protection and fair play. Through advanced monitoring tools, self-exclusion options, and data-driven insights, inplaySoft ensures that players can enjoy their gaming experience safely and responsibly. 

To know more about us, click here to access our website or contact us at sales@inplaysoft.com!

item.title: How Much Do Brazilians Really Bet?
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
Around 94% of sports betting deposits made by Brazilians between January and February of 2025, the first two months with the iGaming market fully regulated in Brazil, were up to R$100. The data comes from a research conducted by Pay4Fun and is based on transactions carried out at online betting houses intermediated by the company.

Transactions that exceed R$ 1,000, on the other hand, represent only 1.4% of the total. Deposits above R$ 2,500 corresponded to less than 0.3%.

Payment methods

The most widely used payment method by online bettors in Brazil is Pix, an instant payment system developed by Brazil's Central Bank that allows fast, free, and secure money transfers 24/7 using keys like phone numbers or email addresses. According to the survey, the instant payment system accounts for 96.72% of transactions carried out on betting platforms from January to December 2024.

Other payment methods have a much lower adoption rate. Electronic wallets, for instance, account for only 1.47% of transactions, bank transfers for 1.36%, and bank slips for 0.45%.

How much do Brazilians bet?

According to a research from Raio X do Investidor Brasileiro, conducted by the Brazilian Association of Financial and Capital Market Entities (Anbima) and Datafolha, Brazilian bettors spend, on average, R$ 216 per month on bets. 

Given that more than 15% of Brazilians, or over 23 million people, made at least one sporting bet in 2024, it is estimated that over R$ 20 billion are already being wagered monthly in betting platforms in Brazil. The Central Bank of Brazil (CBC) indicates that close to 93% of this money ends up returning to bettors as prizes.

Who bets in Brazil?

The survey also investigated the profile of the Brazilian bettor. Regarding sex and age, the majority identified as men from generation Z (16 to 28 years old). As to social class, 16% of bettors are from classes A and B, while 17% are from class C and 10% from classes D and E.

 "The assessment that bets are related to the lower classes is not true", said Marcelo Billi, superintendent of sustainability, innovation and education at Anbima.

Traffic to betting platforms

After Brazil changed its legislation and regulations in the last year, the traffic in betting platforms increased 90%. According to a survey conducted by the website Aposta Legal, iGaming sites received more than 5 billion visits in the first quarter of 2025. This volume of visits is equivalent to over 650 pages accessed per second.

According to the Betting Management System (Sigap), which began overseeing the activities of this industry in the country, in just over three months, the system monitored millions of data points from legalized gambling companies.

Sigap was developed by the Federal Data Processing Service (Serpro) for the SPA, part of the Ministry of Finance. “With just three months since operators started sending data, the system has already received approximately 500,000 sports betting files, 330,000 online gaming files, 600,000 wallet files, and 260,000 bettor records, totaling 1.69 million files in the database. This represents an average of 500 million daily records (each file can contain up to 7,000 records), with 77 authorized operators and 174 brands operating in this sector,” explained Kamila Duarte, manager at Serpro.

Contact inplaySoft

Considering the fact that, with a population of over 215 million people, Brazil is the seventh most populous country on the planet, regulating iGaming opened up a huge market opportunity for online casinos and sports betting platforms. And, if you’re not 100% happy with your current iGaming platform provider, move your casino and sportsbook to inplaySoft (we can help you start from zero too) for a quick and sustained route to ongoing growth.

To know more about us, access inplaySoft's website or contact us at sales@inplaysoft.com!

item.title: An Important Milestone in the Fight Against Match-Fixing in Brazil
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
The International Betting Integrity Association (IBIA) signed a cooperation agreement on online sports betting integrity with the Ministry of Sports of Brazil. According to IBIA, the partnership will enable the exchange of information on suspicious betting activity related to Brazilian sports and support collaboration on integrity-related investigations.

Industry data from H2 Gambling Capital suggests that IBIA currently covers more than 70% of the licensed online betting market in Brazil. Furthermore, the study “The Availability of Sports Betting Products: An Economic and Integrity Analysis” revealed that the Brazilian sports betting market is expected to generate revenues of US$ 34 billion (R$ 191 billion, at the current exchange rate) by 2028. This growth brings to IBIA a responsibility to protect customers, sports and betting operators against match-fixing. 

Brazil’s new regulations

In addition, a key element of the new Brazilian regulatory framework is the requirement for operators to adhere to an independent sports integrity oversight body. According to IBIA, this licensing requirement helps to strengthen its ability to monitor, evaluate and protect betting transactions in Brazil’s newly regulated market.

André Fufuca, Minister of Sports in Brazil, said that: “This is a milestone in the fight against match-fixing in Brazilian sport. Integrity must be a constant principle when it comes to transparency, ethics and, above all, the accuracy of sports results.”

“With these agreements, we will have more than enough tools to curb this practice and ensure greater transparency in competitions. This way, athletes, clubs, organizations, fans and the entire population will be able to have full confidence in the fairness of the results and, therefore, have the peace of mind to develop the full potential of Brazilian sport,” he added.

IBIA’s sport betting monitoring

IBIA monitors more than US$ 300 million (around R$ 1.6 billion) per year in sports betting across more than 140 sports betting brands worldwide, making it “the largest betting integrity monitor of its kind for private operators”.

Khalid Ali, IBIA CEO, said that “IBIA welcomes this important partnership with the Brazilian Ministry of Sport. As the market grows, so does the responsibility to ensure strong integrity safeguards are in place. This agreement will ensure that information about suspicious betting is shared promptly with the ministry to support effective integrity actions. This includes access to detailed account-level data, only available through IBIA’s dedicated network,” he added.

Brazilian betting market

The Brazilian betting market experienced an exponential growth in the last few years. According to the Central Bank of Brazil, Brazilians spent R$ 20 billion per month in 2024 and the number could reach R$ 30 billion by the end of 2025, which will be the first year of the regulated market in the country.

The visits to betting platforms, in turn, increased by 90% in the first quarter of 2025 when compared to the last quarter. In January 2025, there were 1.7 billion visits to betting platforms, followed by 1.4 billion visits in February, and 1.8 billion in March.

If this trend continues, Brazil could become one of the largest iGaming markets in the world. With a population of over 215 million people, Brazil is the seventh most populous country on the planet and its love for sports, specially soccer, makes it extremely attractive for sports betting companies.

item.title: Global provider strengthens its presence in Brazil following local-first event participation
item.dc:creator: Ricardo_A
item.content:encoded:
inplaySoft, an international provider of technological solutions for iGaming in casinos and sports betting operators, participated as an exhibitor at Gambling Brasil 2025. The event took place from May 29 to 31 at the Frei Caneca Convention Center in São Paulo.

Now in its third edition, Gambling Brasil has established itself as one of the main meeting points for the sports betting, casino, and online gaming industries. The event runs in parallel with Afiliados Brasil 2025, the largest affiliate marketing conference in Latin America. Its goal is to bring together top professionals and companies in the sector in an environment conducive to networking, experience exchange, and business generation. Last year, the event welcomed 8,725 attendees.

“In recent years, by analyzing our clients and the market, we’ve found it very relevant to be present. Operators are always looking for a more versatile solution, more reliable data and, most importantly, a platform for casino and sportsbook that scales easily and that continues to receive strong support after the initial agreement. Their goal is to achieve increasingly better numbers and since we’re able to provide that, it became obvious that our presence here wasn’t optional,” says Matheus Correa Lopes, Account Manager at inplaySoft.

Known for the innovation and robustness of its platform, inplaySoft reaffirms its commitment to expanding its presence in the Brazilian and Latin American markets through its participation in the event.

“We are living in the age of artificial intelligence, and we’re moving fast in that direction, bringing increasingly innovative solutions. While we offer diverse and technologically advanced solutions, with automatic scaling, we also deliver something essential: stability with first-class service. Our role is to ensure this solid foundation so operators can focus on what really matters — attracting and retaining players with safety and confidence,” affirms Matheus.

inplaySoft’s presence at the event is further strengthened by its recent success at the iGaming Summit (BiS) SiGMA Americas, one of the largest industry events in Latin America. At the summit, the company held over 100 meetings with potential clients and partners, significantly increasing its visibility in the market.

For more information about inplaySoft, visit https://inplaysoft.com.
